Light also carries energy, and the amount of energy depends on the wavelength: the shorter the wavelength, the more energetic the light beam is. Take short wavelength UV light for example: a little is good for the tan, but too much can cause sunburns! Conversely, longer wavelengths are associated with weaker energies. FM radio emissions for example, are harmless to us. In the Universe at large, energetic phenomenon like supernovae emits lots of X-Rays and Gamma Ray which are even more energetic than UV. But the cold gas lying in between stars, or some cold dust particles for example, emit low energy radiations at long wavelengths that fall into the Radio domain.

trans-unit.id: Kilometre wavelengths propagate through surface waves and follow the curvature of the Earth. With enough emission power, they can reach up to 1000 km. They also propagate under water, that’s why they are often used by submarines. Be careful though, it’s not Sonar! Sonar stands for SOund Navigation And Ranging. It’s a technique that uses sound propagation underwater, not light! Amateur radio operators use decametre wavelengths. These wavelengths are very interesting because they are reflected by the Earth’s ionosphere. This means that an amateur radio signal sent to the sky bounces onto the ionosphere back to Earth, and propagates very far. Sometimes it can even reach the antipodes! Why sometimes? Well the reflection processes depends on the state of the ionosphere. Wavelengths below about a metre propagate directly in straight lines from the emitter, almost like visible light. It’s the domain of FM broadcasting, TV emission, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, etc. These wavelengths are less affected by the ionosphere, that’s why we need satellites to relay them and send them back to Earth.

So radio waves are light, not sound. How come I can listen to my favourite songs with my radio? Well, suppose you want to share a song with your friend, 100m away from you. You could shout it very loudly but it would require a huge amount of energy to be heard, which would most likely result in a sore throat and some angry neighbours… Instead you could use your flashlight, translate it into Morse code and send it to your friend. By doing that, you have solved the problem of energy and distance, but you have lost a lot of information in the process. To keep all the information, you have to code the light you are sending in a specific way, so that your friend can receive and decode it easily. This is called signal processing. Frequency Modulation (FM yes, like in FM radio!) is a kind of signal processing that is very easy and cheap to implement. You just modulate the light signal you are sending (the carrier wave) by varying its instantaneous frequency according to that of your message (your song for example). The signal is sent «modulated», and your radio «demodulates» it back to its original form and transmits it to its speakers, thus converting light back into sound!

Pour garder toute l'information, you devrez coder la lumière que vous envoyez d'une manière plus spécifique, pour que votre ami puisse la recevoir et la décoder facilement. Cela s'appelle du traitement du signal. La modulation de fréquence (oui FM, comme la radio FM !) est un type de traitement du signal qui est très facile et peu couteux à mettre en place. Il suffit de moduler la lumière envoyée (la porteuse) en faisant varier sa fréquence en fonction de la fréquence du signal de votre message (votre chanson par exemple). Le signal est envoyé modulé, et votre radio le démodule à sa forme original et le transmet aux enceintes, convertissant ainsi la lumière en son !

trans-unit.id: The ionosphere is a layer of electrons and other electrically charged particles in the upper atmosphere. It starts at around 80 km from the ground. At this altitude, the atmosphere is too thin to shield the particles from the Solar radiation. Atoms and molecules are hit directly with very energetic light like UV and X-Ray, and this causes them to break and lose some electrons. Their neutral balance is disturbed and they become electrically charged. The resulting mixture of electrons and charged particles is called plasma, and it is responsible for the reflection power of the ionosphere at decametre wavelengths. During the day, Sunbeams hit the ionosphere and produce a lot of charged particles; the ionosphere becomes unstable and cannot reflect the radio signals very efficiently. But at night, the ionosphere is less perturbed and almost acts as a smooth mirror. This is why amateur radio operators prefer to send their long-distance call during the night!

While light can propagate in empty spaces, sound cannot. This is because sound waves need a medium they can vibrate into. You can listen to a piano melody because each time the pianist presses a key, a small hammer hits a string and makes it vibrate. The vibration then propagates into the air, until it reaches a receiver like a human ear for example. The ear is in fact a small vibrating membrane (the ear-drum) connected to small bones that transmits the vibration to our nervous system.

trans-unit.id: Why do astronomers use
very big telescopes?

One crucial parameter when observing the sky is the spatial resolution. The spatial resolution is the smallest detail a telescope can observe. The smaller it is, the more details you will observe on your source. The resolution of a telescope, Θ, is proportional to the wavelength, λ, at which you are observing, and inversely proportional to the diameter of the telescope, Φ. Or simply put: So, the more precision we want, the bigger the telescope must be, especially at high wavelengths. How big? Well, let’s do the maths. Let say I want to see someone standing on the Moon with an optical telescope., and to see him with a bit of detail, I want to make an image of him that has a height of 10 pixels. The man on the Moon is 2m tall. First, let’s calculate his apparent size. The apparent size is the angle δ under which an object of size d is seen at a distance D. Using trigonometric relations, it’s fairly easy to find that sin(δ) = d/D. As δ is very small, this simplifies to δ ≈ d/D.

And the spatial resolution issue becomes critical at longer wavelengths. For radio observations, the telescopes are gigantic.

trans-unit.id: Take for example the Arecibo Observatory: this huge telescope of 305 m diameter is the largest telescope ever built. It is located on the island of Puerto Rico, in the Caribbean. It observes a wide area of centimetre wavelengths. Its impressive size has earned him several appearances in movies, like in the James Bond film: GoldenEye. Another example is the Nançay Radio Telescope in France: Located 2h south of Paris in the Sologne forest near Orleans, this 460 m long radio telescope has two huge mirrors: a plane one of 200x40 m and a spherical one of 300x35 m. Centimetre radio waves are collected by the focal carriage at the centre of the instrument. The plane mirror is movable vertically, only allowing observations of objects passing through the local meridian. It is thus called a meridian instrument.

trans-unit.id: In a simple two-element radio interferometer, the signals from source alternately arrive in phase and out of phase as the Earth rotates and causes a change in the difference in path (the “d” on the picture) from the radio source to the two elements of the interferometer. This produces interference fringes in a manner similar to what was shown in the double slit experiment with visible light. If the radio source has finite angular size, then “d” varies across the source. The measured interference fringes from the interferometer pair thus depend on the detailed nature of the radio «brightness» distribution in the sky. For a radio interferometer with several antennas, each pair produces different fringes, and information from the fringes can be used to reconstruct the original image.

trans-unit.id: What is the receiver made of? As we are going to tackle the technical aspect of radio observations, we should adapt a bit our vocabulary. It will be more practical to talk about frequencies instead of wavelengths, because hardware sample the incoming signal at a certain frequency rate. The small antenna is then linked to a filter that selects the range of frequencies around the frequency of interest. A high frequency amplifier boosts the resulting signal. Once amplified, the trick is to convert the analog signal (a smoothly variating voltage) to a digital signal (an encoded version). But the source frequencies are too high to be sampled with any ordinary hardware! The sample rate is just too high, even an expensive state-of-the-art analog to digital converter could not do it… But here is a simple solution: why not shift the frequency to a much lower one, so that it can be analysed?! Well, this is called heterodyne detection, and it is a technique that is frequently used in radio reception, not only in astronomy, but also in communication.

Une fois amplifié, il faut convertir le signal analogique (une variation de voltage) en signal digital (une version codée du signal). Mais les fréquences des sources radio sont trop hautes pour être directement échantillonnées par du matériel ordinaire ! Le taux d'échantillonnage est trop grand, même pour un convertisseur analogique numérique (CAN) haut de gamme très cher... Et pourquoi pas baisser la fréquence du signal pour qu'il soit analysable ? Et bien c'est possible, et cela s'appelle la détection hétérodyne. C'est une technique fréquemment utilisée en radio, non seulement en astronomie, mais aussi pour les communications.

trans-unit.id: In heterodyne detection, the signal is mixed with a known signal, generated locally by a stable laser. It is called the Local Oscillator. The Local Oscillator has a frequency (FLO) close to that of the sky signal (FSKY), and it can be tuned so that the difference between FLO and FSKY is equal to a fixed frequency that is called the Intermediate Frequency. To put it simply: F SKY - F LO = F Intermediate The Intermediate Frequency is just the right frequency to be sampled by cheaper hardware, less difficult to build and more reliable. Once converted into bits, the signal can be analysed by software and shifted back to the real observed frequency just by numerically adding back again FLO.

Il a une fréquence (FOL) proche de celle du signal venant du ciel (FCIEL). Dit simplement : FCIEL - FOL = F intermédiaire La fréquence intermédiaire et assez basse pour être échantillonnée par un matériel peu cher, facile à réaliser et plus fiable. Une fois converti en signaux numériques, le signal peut être analysé par des programmes informatiques et on peut facilement retrouver la fréquence de la source en rajoutant numériquement FOL.

Souvenez-vous, nos yeux ne peuvent pas voir les ondes radio, il faut donc utiliser une échelle de couleur pour représenter les intensités : ici bleu correspond à un signal faible, et rouge à un signal intense. Ce qui veut dire que plus c'est rouge, et plus il y a de molécules !

trans-unit.target: Grâce à l'effet Doppler ! L'effet Doppler est le décalage en longueur d'onde d'une onde émise d'une source en mouvement par rapport à son observateur. Vous pouvez faire l'expérience de l'effet Doppler quand un véhicule avec une sirène approche, vous dépasse et s'éloigne de vous. C'est ce son caractéristique niiiiiiiiuuuuuuuuuum !! La lumière, comme c'est aussi une onde, se comporte de la même manière :

trans-unit.id: As the photon approaches, its wavelength is shortened in front of it. If it’s originally a yellow photon, then it’s colour turns to blue. We call that a blueshift. If the photon is going away, then that’s the other way around, the wavelength becomes longer. For our yellow photon, its colour turns to red. It’s a redshift! So the Doppler effect gives information about the speed of what we are observing. For example, you can see if a star if moving away from us or if it’s coming in our direction, and we can know at what speed it moves. It’s very useful because knowing the kinematic of the object you are observing allow you to try to reproduce it’s behaviour with computer programs, it’s called modelling. Once you have reproduce a computer model that fits a lot of observation, you can apply it to predict other observations, or guess what’s going to happen to your source in a billion years. For example, with a 3m telescope, you can observe the hydrogen emission line at 21cm. Pointing it to the Milky Way will give you a spectrum, which in that case is the density of hydrogen with respect to its velocity. If along your line of sight you intercepted two spiral arms of the Milky Way moving at a different speed, your spectrum will have two peaks, each at the velocity of its respective arm. So, with radio observation, I can reconstruct the spiral arms of the Milky Way. How cool is that?!

trans-unit.target: Quand le photon approche, sa longueur d'onde se raccourcit devant lui. Si c'est un photon jaune, il devient bleu. Cela s'appelle un décalage vers le bleu (ou blueshift en anglais). Quand le photon s'éloigne, c'est l'inverse, la longueur d'onde s'étire. Notre photon jaune devient rouge. C'est un décalage vers le rouge (ou redshift) ! Donc l'effet Doppler nous donne des informations sur la vitesse de la source observée. C'est très utile car l'étude cinématique d'une source permet de la modéliser et de la reproduire avec un programme informatique. Une fois qu'un modèle fiable est établi, il peut être utilisé pour prédire des observations, ou deviner ce qu'il va arriver à une source dans un milliard d'années. Par exemple, avec un télescope de 3m, on peut observer l'émission de l'hydrogène à 21cm. En observant la Voie Lactée, on obtient un spectre, qui est dans ce cas la répartition de la densité d'hydrogène en fonction de sa vitesse. Si deux bras spiraux ayant deux vitesses différentes ont été interceptés dans la ligne de visée, le spectre comportera deux pics, chacun à la vitesse de son bras respectif. Donc, avec des observations radio, je peux reconstruire la structure spiral de la Voie Lactée. Cool non ?!

trans-unit.source: My supervisor, the famous Jan Oort, asked me to find atomic lines in the radio domain. I found an interesting one: it is the hyperfine transition of neutral hydrogen. If my calculations are correct, this line should be at a wavelength of 21 cm. It should be a weak emission, but, hey, hydrogen is the most abundant atom in the Universe. Why not trying to observe it?
trans-unit.target: Mon superviseur, le fameux Jan Oort, m'a demandé de trouver des raies d'émission atomiques dans le domaine radio. J'en ai trouvé une intéressante : elle provient de la transition hyperfine de l'hydrogène. Si mes calculs sont corrects, cette émission devrait correspondre à une longueur d'onde de 21cm. Cela devrait être une émission très faible, mais bon, l'hydrogène est l'atome le plus abondant dans l'Univers. Pourquoi ne paps essayer de l'observer ?

trans-unit.id: Edward Mills Purcell and Harold Irving Ewen You are right! We built a 1 m x 1 m horn antenna and we detected the 21 cm line! Think about all the implication for radio astronomy! At 21cm the radiation from neutral hydrogen penetrates much farther than visible light, and it is the most abundant atom in the Universe! That means that we can observe large structures, like other galaxies, very far away.

Pensez à toutes les implications pour la radio astronomie ! A 21cm, le rayonnement pénètre beaucoup plus loin que la lumière visible, et l'hydrogène est l'atome le plus abondant de l'Univers ! Cela veut dire que nous pouvons avoir accès aux grandes structures, comme celles des galaxies, situées très loin !

We think we just found something very interesting for radio astronomy. We are working at the Bell Telephone Company, and we built an antenna that was originally used to communicate with satellites Echo and Telstar 1 (the first telecommunication satellites ever launched). We accidentally discovered an additional noise of unknown origin during observations on the wavelength 7.35 cm. This noise corresponds to a sky temperature of 2.7 K. And it fills the entire sky almost uniformly! We think that we detected the Cosmic Microwave Background predicted by the Big Bang theory.
